Context: The School of Marketing at George Brown College offers students opportunities to build on their knowledge and skills through extracurricular activities. These activities include participation in competitions like the Ontario Colleges Marketing Competition, Vanier BDC Case Challenge, Enactus George Brown, speed mentoring events, and the Great Canadian Sales Competition. The Centre for Business programs within the School of Marketing are accredited by the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP), making them internationally recognized. Students are required to bring their own laptops due to a Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) initiative, but open access computers and equipment borrowing are also available at the Library Learning Commons. Students have the option of earning a business elective credit through the Field Education Course (BUS 1067), which often involves case studies and projects with industry partners. George Brown Marketing students have access to membership in two Canadian marketing associations, the CMA and IAB, included in their tuition fees. The CMA membership includes live and online events with member pricing, professional development opportunities, and tools, resources, and guides.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Business – Marketing Program B120 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides information about the benefits and courses of a marketing program offered by George Brown College in Canada. Here is the extracted information:

* The program offers events with free or reduced member pricing, professional development opportunities, tools, resources, and guides for members only, networking opportunities with thousands of marketers, and exclusive access to CMA NXT and IAB.
* CMA NXT is a site dedicated to filling the gap between post-secondary education and professional life. IAB membership includes student volunteer opportunities, members-only webinars and podcasts, original Canadian digital marketing research, globally accepted digital ad standards, and globally standardized courses, certification, and custom workshops.
* Graduates are prepared for careers in various business sectors including marketing firms, advertising agencies, retailers, banks and other financial services institutions, government, not-for-profit, and small businesses. Potential positions may include marketing assistant, sales representative, customer service representative, account coordinator, brand ambassador, and advertising assistant.
* The program has a pathway to the Business Administration – Marketing three-year advanced diploma program. Students can benefit from a seamless transition into the three-year advanced diploma. George Brown College has agreements with several colleges and universities in Canada and abroad that will give students credit for their college diploma.
* In order to graduate from the B120 program, students need to complete 26 courses: 23 mandatory courses and 3 general education electives. Depending on the results of placement tests, students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) or MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) before progressing to other courses. These extra courses do not count toward the 26 courses required for graduation and will be charged separately.
* Students must complete three General Education courses chosen from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences, Arts and Humanities, or Science and Technology.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Business – Marketing Program B120 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides information about the curriculum plan for a college program, likely in Business or Marketing, spanning across four semesters. The following courses are listed for each semester along with their prerequisites:

SEMESTER 1:
- BUS 1038: Business Concepts I (NONE)
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts (NONE)
- COMP 1010: Business Computer Applications I (NONE)
- MARK 1020: Principles of Marketing I (NONE)
- MATH 1008: Math for Business & Management (NONE)
- MARK 1046: Marketing Today (NONE)

SEMESTER 2:
- ACCT 1036: Principals of Accounting (NONE)
- COMM 1034: Professional Communication (COMM 2000)
- COMP 1115: Business Computer Applications II (COMP 1010)
- MARK 2049: Principles of Marketing II (MARK 1020 & MARK 1046)
- MATH 1131: Mathematical Analysis for Marketers (MATH 1008)
- CMMK 1087: Human Skills (NONE)
- Select One General Education Elective

SEMESTER 3:
- CMMK 2034: Communication for Marketers (COMM 1034)
- ECON 1034: Introduction to Economics (NONE)
- MARK 1055: Integrated Marketing Communication I (MARK 2049 & MARK 2007)
- MATH 1131: Mathematical Analysis for Marketers
- PSY 1129: Organizational Behaviour (NONE)
- Select One General Education Elective

SEMESTER 4:
- BUS 1056: Business Presentation Skills (COMM 1007)
- MARK 1002: Professional Selling (MARK 1020)
- MARK 2033: Database Marketing I (MARK 2049)
- MARK 2069: Digital Marketing I (MARK 2049)
- MATH 1131: Mathematical Analysis for Marketers

It is important to note that students may need to make up any failed or dropped courses before graduation and can do so during the day, with some offered in the evening through Continuing Education. Students should check with the business office staff to ensure that Continuing Education courses are equivalent to what is taught in the full-time program. Some courses may not be offered every semester. The college provides assistance for any special timetable requirements students may have.

Context:
The text provides information about a Marketing program offered by the college. The program includes the following courses: Digital Marketing I (MARK 2049) and Career Planning for Marketing (MARK 2065). The graduate of this program is expected to be able to contribute to various marketing activities such as developing marketing plans, integrated marketing communication plans, new marketing concepts, and sales presentations.

Program Learning Outcomes:
- Contribute to the development of a marketing plan that will meet the needs or goals of a business or organization.
- Contribute to the development of an integrated marketing communication plan of a product, concept, good and/or service based on an identified market need or target.
- Contribute to the development of new and/or modified marketing concepts, products, goods and/or services that respond to market needs.
- Contribute to the development of strategies for the efficient and effective placement/distribution of a product, good and/or service to respond to an evolving market.
- Contribute to the development of strategies related to pricing for a product, good and/or service.
- Analyze the viability of a concept, product, good and/or service in local, national or global markets.
- Participate in conducting market research to provide information needed to make marketing decisions.
- Communicate marketing information persuasively and accurately, in oral, written, graphic and interactive media formats.
- Plan, prepare and deliver a sales presentation or pitch to address the needs of the client.
- Develop strategies with clients, customers, consumers, co-workers, supervisors and others to maintain and grow working relationships.
- Develop learning and development strategies to enhance professional growth in the field.
- Apply entrepreneurial strategies to identify and respond to new career opportunities that might include contract employment, and self-employment initiatives.
- Operate within a framework of organizational policies and practices, when conducting business of the organization.

Tuition and Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $4,509.00 for the first two semesters (Fall 2022)
- International Tuition: $17,455.00 for the first two semesters (Fall 2023)

*Please note that fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and at later dates.*

Additional costs are not specified in the text. For more information about international students, visit the "International Fees and Related Costs" page.

Context:
The George Brown College offers various programs with specific requirements for international and domestic students. Here's the extracted information from the text:

1. Financial Assistance: The college program is approved for Ontario Student Assistance Program (OSAP) funding, given that the applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria.
2. Admission Requirements: Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or its equivalent, English grade 12 (C or U), and math grade 11 (C, M, or U) or math grade 12 (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or consider upgrading to achieve the required credits in English and math.
3. Course Exemptions: Some college and university credits might grant exemptions. For more details, check out the transfer guide.
4. Contact Information:
   - Domestic Students: For queries about domestic admission requirements, deadlines, or the admissions process, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions section.
   - International Students: Visit the How to Apply page for more information on how and when to apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
5. Information Sessions: Sign up for an upcoming on-campus information session.
6. Important Disclaimer: The college's website information may change without notice, and it should not be considered a representation or warranty. Students are responsible for verifying George Brown College fee requirements.
7. International Students: Visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.

Context:
International Student Admissions:
- Contact international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry through the International Contact Us page.
- For financial inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section.
- To get advice on program options and suitability, make an appointment to see an Entry Advisor.
- Centre for Business: Contact business@georgebrown.ca or (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160. Program-related inquiries should be directed to the program coordinator Adrian Bond at abond@georgebrown.ca or John Peco, Chair of the School of Marketing, at john.peco@georgebrown.ca.
- Campus tours are offered and classes for the Business – Marketing (B120) program usually take place at George Brown College's St. James Campus, located mainly at 200 King St. E. and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
- Sign up for a campus tour or check out the virtual tour on the website.
- Follow the Centre for Business on Instagram and LinkedIn.
- Related programs include Business Administration – Marketing (B108), Marketing Management – Digital Media (Postgraduate) (B433), and Business Administration – Marketing (with work experience) (B158).
